Ha, uh no. This is a massive, massive misconception. And at the point an outright lie. Artificial banana flavor doesn’t taste like banana, because there are over 40 different molecules that contribute to the flavor in actual bananas. The most volatile, is  isoamyl acetate, and this compound is whats used in artificial banana flavors. The reason that we don’t use the other 40 or so compounds to make a more realistic artificial banana flavor, is because it would be expensive to synthesize, among other things. Isoamyl acetate happens to be the most banana’y (yes I know that’s not a real work) of the compounds on it’s own, and it also happens to be really cheap to produce. So no, it’s not based on the Gros Michel, this is just a myth made up to explain the disparity between the flavor of real bananas, and artificial banana. Please do some research guys. It’s not that hard. Don’t believe everything you hear online.

I'm a food scientist and here comes a fun fact: isoamyl acetate is the main compound of the typical banana flavour in both the Gros Michel as well as the Cavendish. The difference is the concentration, the Gros Michel has more of that esther. So if a banana candy tastes artifical, it just contains too much of that compound.

Another fact: there are scientists that actually try to bring back the Gros Michel by genetically modifiying it for a better resistance to the fungus 🎉.

Absolutely true, and I love you guys and your work, but for the love of all that is linguistically holy in English, FFS never, ever use the phrase "based off of." By its very definition, a thing cannot be based off of something, because then it's not based on anything. The only proper way to put it is "this was based on that." Period. Full stop.

To put it in sciencey terms, saying "based off of" is just as jarring as saying "1 + 2 = approximately 4." Nope.

Bananas are grown as clones of each other, meaning they have virtually no genetic diversity, which is why the fungal infection that wiped out the Gros Michel (TR1) alliterated whole population.

The cavendish was resistant to TR1, which is why it replaced the Gros Michel as the dominant banana type, but what wasn’t mentioned in this video is that the same fate may befall the cavendish. The cavendish was resistant to TR1, but now TR4 (another fungal strain) is wiping many of them out. And again, these bananas are all clones! Which means the entire population of cavendish bananas could go just like the gros Michel.
